title-group.article-title: Metabolites isolated from the human intestinal fungus Penicillium oxalicum SL2 and their agonistic effects on PXR and FXR

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Metabolites isolated from the human intestinal fungus
Penicillium oxalicum
SL2 and their agonistic effects on PXR and FXR

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Wen-Yu Zhao a, 1 , Zhi-Lin Luan a, 1 , Cheng-Peng Sun a, 1 , Bao-Jing Zhang a , Ling-Ling Jin a ,
Sa Deng a , Hou-Li Zhang a , Zhen-Long Yu a , Chao Wang
a, * , Xiao-Chi Ma

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Penicillium oxalicum SL
2 Trichocomaceae Metabolites
FXR
PXR
ABSTRACT

Intestinal commensal fungi are vital to human health, and their metabolites play a key role in the reciprocal relationship. In the present work, eighteen alkaloids and seven monoterpenoids were isolated from the fermentation of the human intestinal fungus
Penicillium oxalicum SL
2, including seven undescribed alkaloids (penicilloxalines A-G), three undescribed monoterpenoids (penicilloxalines H-J), and fifteen reported compounds. The structures of the isolated compounds were identified by HRESIMS, 1D and 2D NMR, electronic circular dichroism spectra and quantum chemical calculations. Some metabolites displayed moderate agonistic effects against the pregnane X receptor (PXR), whereas (6 R )3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2( Z )-octenoic acid displayed a significant agonistic effect against the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) with an EC 50 value of 0.43 μ M, which was verified by investigating FXR downstream target genes and proteins, such as small heterodimer partner 1 (SHP1), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), and bile salt export pump (BSEP).

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Herein, the metabolites investigation of
Penicillium oxalicum Currie, J.N.
; Thom, C. ( Trichocomaceae ) strain SL2, produced twenty-five compounds, including ten undescribed penicilloxalines A-J and fifteen known penicilloxalines ( Fig. 1 ). Their structures were determined by 1D and 2D NMR, HRESIMS, and electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra as well as time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) ECD calculations. All the isolated compounds were assayed for their agonistic effects toward pregnane X receptor (PXR) and farnesoid X receptor (FXR). Molecular dynamics (MD) was used to further study the underlying interaction of compound 18 with FXR.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure determination of isolated metabolites
sec.p: Penicilloxaline C ( 3 ) had the molecular formula C 13 H 14 N 2 O 6 based on its HRESIMS ( m/z 293.0781 [M H], calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779) and 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ). The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 3 closely resembled those of 2 , except for the downfield shift of C-11 from δ C 163.4 in 2 to δ C 161.9 in 3 , the upfield shift of C-14 from δ C 173.0 in 2 to δ C 173.9 in 3 , and the signals of the methoxy group [ δ C 51.2 and δ H 3.60 (s) in 2 ; δ C 51.9 and δ H 3.82 (s) in 3 ], suggesting their differences at C-11 and C-14. The HMBC correlations of OCH 3 -11 with C-11 confirmed their differences. Thus, the structure of 3 was determined to be penicilloxaline C.

Analysis of HRESIMS data of penicilloxaline D ( 4 ) revealed that 4 possessed a molecular formula of C 14 H 16 N 2 O
6 in
conjunction with its 13 C NMR data. The signals of the two methoxy groups were δ C 51.9 and 52.0 and δ H 3.59 (s) and 3.76 (s) in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 4 , and 4 had a mass that was 14 Da greater than 3 , revealing that 4 was a methylated derivative of 3 . In the HMBC spectrum of 4 , cross-peaks of OCH 3 -14 with C-14 and OCH 3 -11 with C-11 confirmed the linkages of two methoxy moieties. The structure of 4 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as D.

Penicilloxaline E ( 5 ) was obtained as an amorphous powder, and its molecular formula was determined to be C 17 H 14 N 2 O 4 based on the HRESIMS data ( m/z 309.0886 [M H], calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 4 , 309.0881). The 1 H NMR data of 5 displayed the presence of a quinazolinone moiety at δ H 8.10 (1H, s), 8.09 (1H, br d, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.80 (1H, br t, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.60 (1H, br d, J = 7.5 Hz), and 7.52 (1H, br t, J = 7.5 Hz) in combination with the characteristic 13 C NMR data ( δ C 159.9, 147.4 × 2, 134.5, 127.1, 126.9, 126.1, and 121.2) ( Table 3 ). Four aromatic protons were present at δ H 6.90 (2H, d, J = 8.2 Hz) and δ H 6.54 (2H, d, J = 8.2 Hz) in the 1 H NMR spectrum of 5 , and signals of nine representative carbons were present at δ C 170.5, 155.9, 129.7 × 2, 126.9, 115.2 × 2, 59.9, and 33.9 in its 13 C NMR spectrum, which suggested the presence of a tyrosine moiety. The presence of the two abovementioned moieties was further confirmed by the 2D NMR data of 5 . The HMBC correlations of H-12 with C-1/C-9 determined the linkage of a quinazolinone and tyrosine moiety through a nitrogen atom ( Fig. 3 ). The calculated ECD spectrum of (12 S )- 5 agreed well with its experimental ECD spectrum, requiring its absolute configuration ( Fig. 4B ). Accordingly, the structure of 5 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline E ( 5 ).

Penicilloxaline F ( 6 ) had a molecular formula of C 17 H 14 N 2 O 5 according to the [M H] peak at m/z 325.0819 (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 5 , 325.0824) and 13 C NMR data. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 6 closely resembled those of 5 , and their difference was at the right aromatic ring ( Table 3 ). The chemical shift value of C-16 was deshielded from δ C 115.2 in 5 to δ C 145.1 in 6 , and the chemical shift values of C-15, C-17, and C-19 were shielded from δ C 129.8, 156.1, and 129.8 in 5 to δ C 116.1, 143.8, and 119.4 in 6 . The HMBC correlation of H-18 with C-16 suggested the hydrolyzation of C-16. The absolute configuration of 6 was assigned as 12 S through a comparison of its calculated and experimental ECD spectra ( Fig. 4C ). Thus, the structure of 6 was defined in Fig. 1 and referred to as penicilloxaline F ( 6 ).

The molecular formula of penicilloxaline G ( 7 ) was determined to be C 18 H 16 N 2 O 4 based on the HRESIMS and 13 C NMR data. Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 7 and 5 revealed the presence of a methoxy group [ δ C 52.6; δ H 3.69, s] in 7 and the upfield shift of C-11 from δ C 170.5 in 5 to δ C 169.3 in 7 . The HMBC cross-peaks of OCH 3 -11 with C-11 suggested that 7 was a methylation derivative of 5 . Its absolute configuration was determined to be 12 S based on the result of the quantum chemical calculation ( Fig. 4D ). Therefore, the structure of 7 is shown in Fig. 1 and is referred to as penicilloxaline G.

The molecular formula of penicilloxaline J ( 10 ) was defined as C 10 H 16 O 4 by HRESIMS and 13 C NMR data. A detailed comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 10 and (6 S )-3,7-dimethyl-6,7-dihydroxy-2( Z )- octenoic acid ( 15 ) demonstrated that 10 was a 6-oxo derivative of 15 because of the downfield shift of C-6 from δ C 72.7 in 15 to δ C 215.0 in 10 (
). In the HMBC spectrum of 10 , correlations of CH 3 -8/ CH 3 -10 with C-6 confirmed the deduction. The configuration of the Δ 2(3) olefinic moiety in 10 was identical to that of 8 and 9 according to similar 13 C NMR data and the biosynthetic background. Therefore, the structure of penicilloxaline J ( 10 ) was determined as shown in Fig. 1 .
2.2. Agonistic effects of isolated metabolites against PXR and FXR

These isolated compounds were assayed for their agonistic effects against PXR and FXR. Compounds 5 , 11 , 19 , and 22 exhibited significant agonistic effects against PXR with EC 50 values of 7.73, 4.04, 0.12, and 0.21 μ M, respectively, whereas compound 18 displayed a significant agonistic effect against FXR with an EC 50 value of 0.43 μ M ( Table 5 ).

To confirm the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR, the mRNA and protein expression levels of FXR and its downstream targets, such as SHP1, BSEP, and FGF, were investigated after 24 h incubation of compound 18 (2 μ M) with HepG2 cells. As shown in Fig. 5A–C , administration of compound 18 (2 μ M) resulted in the upregulation of the mRNA levels of FXR, SHP1, and BSEP, and expression levels of FXR, SHP1, FGF, and BSEP were increased after the administration of compound 18 (2 μ M). FXR is a nuclear transcription factor, and its nuclear translocation leads to the binding of its downstream target genes; therefore, we investigated the transcriptional regulation of FXR modulated by compound 18 . As described in Fig. 6 , the translocation of FXR from the cytoplasm to the nucleus was observed after treatment with compound 18 . These results indicate that compound 18 activated FXR and transcriptionally regulated the expression levels of its downstream targets.

To investigate the potential interaction of compound 18 with FXR, GROMACS software was used to perform a 50-ns MD stimulation. As shown in Fig. 7A–C , the RMSD of compound 18 with FXR remained under 2 Å, the RMSF of residues ranged from 0.5 Å to 3.5 Å, and the pocket volume of FXR remained at approximately 1000 Å
3 in
the presence of compound 18 during a 50-ns MD stimulation, which suggests that this MD stimulation was reliable. Compound 18 could form a stable complex with FXR with an energy of approximately 5.8 × 10 5 kJ/mol during a 50-ns MD stimulation ( Fig. 7D ). The total binding energy was 78.383 kJ/mol, indicating that compound 18 had a good binding effect with FXR. The energy contribution results indicated that the van der Waals interaction energy (177.442 kJ/mol) was strong, the electrostatic (35.666 kJ/mol) and SASA nonpolar solvent (13.918 kJ/mol) interaction energy was weak, and polar solvation (88.643 kJ/mol) hindered the binding of compound 18 and FXR ( Fig. 7E ). During the 50- ns MD stimulation, Compound 18 could form 1–4 hydrogen bonds with four amino acid residues, Val325, Met328, Phe329, Ser332, and Tyr369 ( Fig. 7F ). The distances of compound 18 with amino acid residues Val325, Met328, Phe329, and Tyr369 were monitored by GROMACS. As shown in Fig. 7G, a complex of compound 18 with FXR achieved equilibrium during the 50-ns MD stimulation, whereas Ser332 maintained a distance under 3.0 Å with OH-6 and OH-7 of compound 18 ( Fig. 7H ) after the 50-ns MD stimulation. During the 50-ns MD stimulation ( Fig. 8A ), compound 18 only interacted with Ser332 by way of two hydrogen bonds, indicating the potential role of Ser 332 in the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR.
a Not detected.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
Herein, the investigation of the fermentation of the human intestinal fungus
P. oxalicum SL
2 led to the isolation and identification of twenty-five
compounds (1 – 25), including
seven previously undescribed alkaloid penicilloxalines A ¡ G (
1 – 7
), three previously undescribed monoterpenoid penicilloxalines H-J (
8 – 10
), and fifteen reported compounds (
11 – 25
). Compounds 5 , 11 , 19 , and 22 displayed significant agonist effects against PXR with EC 50 values from 0.12 ¡7.73 μ M, whereas compound 18 gave a significant agonist effect against FXR (EC 50 = 0.43 μ M). MD stimulation revealed hydrogen bonds between the Ser332 amino acid residue of FXR and the 6-OH and 7-OH of compound 18 . Site-directed amino acid mutation confirmed the vital role of Ser 332 in the agonistic effect of compound 18 toward FXR. Therefore, the hydroxyl groups of compound 18 were revealed as the active functional groups of compound 18 .

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental methods
sec.p: An Autopol IV automatic polarimeter was used to measure the optical rotation. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV-600 NMR spectrometer (Bruker, Karlsruhe, Germany ), chemical shift values are expressed in δ (ppm) using the peak signals of the solvent DMSO‑ d 6 ( δ H 2.50 and δ C 39.5) as references, and coupling constants ( J in Hz) are given in parentheses. ECD spectra were measured on a JASCO CD-MDS 450 spectrophotometer.

sec.title: 4.2. Microorganism material
sec.p:
The human intestinal fungus in this work was isolated from human feces and was identified as
Penicillium oxalicum Currie, J.N.
; Thom, C. ( Trichocomaceae ) strain SL2 by Dr. Qiulong Yan using the 18S rDNA sequence. A sample of this fungal strain (ID: P7015) was deposited in the College of Pharmacy, Dalian Medical University.

sec.title: 4.3. Exaction and isolation
sec.p:
The strain
P. oxalicum SL
2 was inoculated into 200 × 1 L Erlenmeyer flasks that contained 140 g rice and 187 mL distilled water and had previously been sterilized by autoclaving at 121 ◦ C for 30 min and then incubated at 28 ◦ C for 30 days. The solid rice media was extracted with EtOAc (80 L) 3 times. After removing the solvent, the residue ( 247 g ) was obtained.

The EtOAc extracts ( 247 g ) were isolated through a silica gel column and eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:1 to 1:1) to afford four fractions: E1 E4. Separation of Fraction E2 ( 48 g ) through silica gel column chromatography afforded four subfractions: E21 E24. Subfraction E21 ( 10 g ) was purified by an ODS column (10%–90% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (50%–80% MeOH) to afford compounds 4 ( 3.7 mg ) and 22 ( 3.7 mg ). Compounds 8 ( 2.8 mg ), 10 ( 5.2 mg ), 15 ( 17.3 mg ), 16 ( 17.1 mg ), and 17 ( 9.1 mg ) were separated from Subfraction E22 ( 8 g ) through ODS column chromatography (10%–90% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (28%–55% MeOH). Subfraction E23 ( 10 g ) was separated by an ODS column and eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (from 1:9 to 9:1) to afford nine subfractions, E231 E239, and compound 2 ( 48 mg ). Subfraction E232 ( 800 mg ) was purified by preparative HPLC (28%–55% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (10%–25% CH 3 CN), yielding compounds 7 ( 6.8 mg ), 12 ( 10.5 mg ), 18 ( 13.1 mg ), and 19 ( 8.6 mg ). Purification of Subfraction E234 ( 712 mg ) through preparative HPLC (35% CH 3 CN) resulted in the production of compounds 3 ( 5.1 mg ) and 23 ( 2.3 mg ). Subfraction E24 ( 10 g ) was subjected to an ODS column and eluted with MeOH–H 2 O (from 1:9 to 7:3) to obtain eight subfractions: E241 E248. Subfraction E242 ( 350 mg ) was isolated by preparative HPLC (10% CH 3 CN) to afford compounds 9 ( 3.9 mg ) and 25 ( 35.8 mg ). Separation of Subfraction E243 ( 821 mg ) through ODS column chromatography (28%–55% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (15%–20% CH 3 CN) afforded compounds 5 ( 7.3 mg ), 14 (4.0 mg), 20 ( 8.4 mg ), and 21 ( 3.5 mg ). Subfraction E246 ( 120 mg ) was purified by preparative HPLC (40% CH 3 CN) to afford compound 24 (2.0 mg).
Finally, Fraction E3 ( 20 g ) was purified by an ODS column (10%– 100% MeOH) and preparative HPLC (30%–50% MeOH), yielding compounds 1 (23.0 mg), 6 ( 3.1 mg ), 11 (10.0 mg), and 13 (9.0 mg).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Penicilloxaline A (1)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D + 43 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 218 (3.8), 260 (3.4) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 232 (7.12), 268 (+4.03); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 452.2926 [M H] (calcd. for C 27 H 38 N 3 O 3 , 452.2919).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Penicilloxaline B (2)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.9), 357 (3.7) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 293.0779 [M H] (calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Penicilloxaline C (3)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 222 (3.7), 351 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 293.0781 [M H] (calcd. for C 13 H 13 N 2 O 6 , 293.0779).

sec.title: 4.3.4. Penicilloxaline D (4)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 222 (3.9), 344 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 307.0936 [M H] (calcd. for C 14 H 15 N 2 O 6 , 307.0936).

sec.title: 4.3.5. Penicilloxaline E (5)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 39 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 227 (3.7), 268 (3.4), 303 (3.2) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 275 (6.11); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 309.0886 [M H] (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 4 , 309.0881).

sec.title: 4.3.6. Penicilloxaline F (6)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 87 ( c 0.3, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 228 (3.9), 277 (3.3) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 213 (5.92), 228 (5.91), 286 (1.82); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 325.0819 [M H] (calcd. for C 17 H 13 N 2 O 5 , 325.0824).

sec.title: 4.3.7. Penicilloxaline G (7)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 62 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 228 (3.9), 268 (3.4), 303 (3.2) nm; ECD (MeOH) nm (Δ ε ) 236 (7.82), 272 (4.95); 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 323.1026 [M H] (calcd. for C 18 H 15 N 2 O 4 , 323.1032).

sec.title: 4.3.8. Penicilloxaline H (8)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D +61 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 202 (3.9) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 287.1503 [M H] (calcd. for C 14 H 23 O 6 , 287.1500).

sec.title: 4.3.9. Penicilloxaline I (9)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]20D 15 ( c 0.2, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.8) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 217.1074 [M H] (calcd. for C 10 H 17 O 5 , 217.1076).

sec.title: 4.3.10. Penicilloxaline J (10)
sec.p: White solid; [ α ]20D 35 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.9) nm; 1 H (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) data, see Table 4 ; HRESIMS m/z 201.1127 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 10 H 17 O 4 , 201.1121).

sec.title: 4.4. ECD calculations
4.5. FXR activation bioassay
4.6. PXR activation bioassay
4.7. Real-time quantitative PCR
sec.p: According to the manufacturer’ s instructions, RNA was extracted from the HepG2 and HK 2 cells after treatment with the compounds for 24 h. Reverse transcription was conducted using a reverse transcription kit ( Beijing , China ). The cDNA was used as a template for RT-qPCR. All primers were designed by Oligo 6.0 software (MBI Inc., Colorado , USA ).

sec.title: 4.8. Western blot
sec.p: Cell samples were lysed in RIPA lysis buffer supplemented with protease and phosphatase inhibitors. The protein concentration was quantified using a BCA Protein Assay Kit (Beyotime Institute of Biotechnology, Hangzhou, China ). The same amount of denatured protein was loaded on denaturing SDS polyacrylamide gels and transferred to polyvinylidene fluoride membranes, which were blocked in 5% skim milk. Membranes were incubated with specific primary antibodies overnight at 4 ◦ C. After washing, the blots were incubated with secondary antibodies for 2 h at room temperature. Blots were revealed with a chemiluminescence (ECL) western blotting system. ImageJ software (Rawak Software Inc., Germany ) was used to quantitate the protein expression level.

sec.title: 4.9. Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: HepG2 c ells were treated with compounds and fixed with 4% PFA after 24 h. Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS three times, treated with 0.3% Triton X-100 for 10 min, and blocked with 0.5% BSA for 30 min. Cells were incubated with primary FXR antibody overnight at 4 ◦ C. Before incubation with the fluorescent secondary antibody for 1 h at room temperature, the cells were washed three times. DAPI was used to stain the nuclei, and the cells were then analyzed under a confocal microscope.

sec.title: 4.10. Molecular dynamics stimulation
Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare no competing financial interest.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112974.
